title: 110_hr5646
content: The Act titled "Protecting the Second Amendment and Hunting Rights on Federal Lands Act of 2008" allows for possessing or carrying firearms and ammunition in units of the National Park System and the National Wildlife Refuge System. Congress finds that the Second Amendment guarantees the right to bear arms and that firearms are used for self-defense over 2,000,000 times a year in the US. States with laws expanding self-defense rights have seen a decrease in firearm-related crime. Federal regulations currently prohibit firearm possession in certain national park and wildlife units. The rights of residents to use firearms for self-defense have led to a decrease in firearm-related crime. Federal regulations currently prohibit firearm possession in units of the National Park System and the National Wildlife Refuge System, hindering individuals from exercising their second amendment rights. Laws regarding transportation and possession are also affected. The regulations in the National Park System and National Wildlife Refuge System often restrict individuals from exercising their second amendment rights, as laws regarding firearms differ from state laws, causing issues for law-abiding gun owners. Federal law should clarify that the second amendment rights of individuals in units of the National Park System or the National Wildlife Refuge System will not be infringed. Federal law should protect the second amendment rights of individuals in the National Park System and the National Wildlife Refuge System, ensuring that no restrictions on possessing or carrying firearms or ammunition are based on their location within these units. Federal law should protect second amendment rights in the National Park System and National Wildlife Refuge System, ensuring no restrictions on possessing firearms based on location. The purpose of this section is to require that hunting activities be included in all Federal land management plans unless clearly incompatible with the land's purposes. The head of the agency must ensure hunting is allowed on Federal land unless it conflicts with the land's management goals. When approving a management plan for Federal land, hunting activities must be allowed unless clearly incompatible with the land's purposes. If hunting is not allowed or restricted, the specific reasons must be included in the management plan. The management plan for Federal land must include specific reasons for not allowing or restricting hunting activities. Excessive fees related to hunting on Federal land will be considered a restriction on hunting. Fees charged for hunting activities on Federal land must be used to offset management costs directly related to hunting on that land. Excessive fees will be considered a restriction on hunting. Fees for hunting on Federal land must be used to cover management costs directly related to hunting activities. Excessive fees will be seen as a restriction on hunting. The Secretary may use fees from hunting on Federal land to offset costs directly related to managing hunting activities. Definitions include hunting, trapping, netting, and fishing. This section applies to all management plans developed, approved, or amended after the enactment date. The management plan for Federal land includes hunting, trapping, netting, and fishing.
